replies.body: rofl i like how you said "there is **literally** NO reason" when the article's whole purpose is to highlight the reasons why it is logistically not worth it. >_< rofl

They give a reason not to fly out the teams. Fair enough. However there is pretty much no reason not to make a live draw (like i said) with  CASTERS/RIOT MEMBERS/NICK ALLEN doing the draw, live, on stream. You don't need to fly out anyone.

That's not what the article says. It says that it's not realistic to wait until one week before Worlds to find out where ALL SIXTEEN teams will be playing during the Group Stage. With a live draw, they will do a drawing of the Groups live and then have about a week to arrange visas and travel plans for all sixteen teams to go to one of the two Group Stage locations. Instead, they did a private draw ahead of time so that as (for example) teams like Samsung Blue clinch the #1 seed, they Riot can start preparing the travel visas, since they will know which location Blue will be going to for Group Stage.

"The only downside would be the possibility of teams throwing games to get placed into a specific group. ***I wouldn't expect teams to do this, but it is a possibility***."

Obviously you don't have any experience with any competitive event at all. If teams have advanced information that can tell them which brackets are easier, of course they will take advantage of it. Doing a live draw and thus giving teams an incentive to fix their ending seed pretty much throws the legitimacy of the World Championships out the window. You don't even have to look that far to see match fixing. LMQ potentially threw their last LCS match to drop their position down to 2nd place where they would be in an arguably easier bracket than they would be if they had secured 1st place. Riot can't afford to risk the legitimacy of the entire tournament by hosting a little side show like a live group draw. Wait until the 2015 season when they synchronize all of the regional tournaments for your live group draw.

Isn't it held in multiple countries?  Getting visas started  and booking flights for every possible seeding doesn't seem nontrivial to me.  Match fixing is also really nonobvious; to take a relatively recent example, Shiphtur may very well have thrown Coast's relegation match (no, I don't actually believe this, but it's an undeniable possibility).  He sure played poorly, and he was likely aware he'd end up on a better team if they got relegated.  The only way we'd ever find out is if he was really stupid and actually said something about intending to play sub-optimally.  Both teams have an incentive to play poorly in the situation Riot fears, just not so poorly that Riot has solid evidence; given the number of throws in  LCS, that leaves a lot of wiggle room.

There should be a simple cryptographic solution to solve this. It would unfortunately not as transparent to the average viewer to do so but it does squash any arguments that groups are rigged. I'm only a masters student, I'm by no means an expert, but I think this would relatively robust once you find an acceptable 3rd party:

1. Construct a message, and encrypt it. Publish the result and the public key.
2. After it's published, have a 3rd party (community vote? the top comment on the published key? bitcoin block chain? stock market?) create a tail string.
3. Concatenate the (unencrypted) message with the tail string and hash that.
4. Use the digest as a seed for a RNG to generate the groups.
5. When groups are safe to be revealed, publish the key to decrypt the private key. Anyone can then verify that groups were seeded randomly

Just needs independent verification that the draw took place and that the results drawn were the ones seen, but this could help with the latter part.  You would still need independent verification to ensure that the groups were actually drawn randomly, and not arbitrarily decided.
